She is studying at Campo Alto and is asking for help because she doesn’t have the money to pay for her fourth semester.  Please cooperate with her so that her fees aren’t so high.  Thank you for helping her, she awaits your prompt response and, in this way, can continue with her studies and get her two children ahead.

loans.use: to pay registration for one semester

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is 21years old and single.  He has run an Internet cafe since August 2012. 

He is a hard worker who provides several different services to his customers in his shop. In addition to Internet games, he serves hookas and coffee and hot drinks as additional income services.  Through this way he provides a better service to his customers.

Today, Mohamad is acquiring a YOUTH loan from Kiva partner's Al Majmoua to improve his business by adding an extra income business.  He will start selling prepaid cards for mobile phones, which will provide his customers with an extra service.

He hopes that through the future expected loans, he will work on expanding his business by buying a billiard table and increasing his computers to serve more customers.

loans.use: To start selling prepaid cards for mobile phones, which will provide his customers with an extra service

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more palm oil to expand her business

loans.name: Yudy Tatiana

texts.es:
Yudy tatiana es una niña que cuando nació los papas estaban orgullosa de ella, ella desde pequeña siempre le gustaron las matemáticas y el deporte, luego de culminar su bachillerato salio con deseos de empezar y su nueva vida, ella comenzó estudiando administración en salud, no era algo que le gustaba porque no se veía lo que le gustaba que eran las matemáticas. Cuando ella llevaba 2 semestres su vida cambio, se dio cuenta de que a la vida de ella llegaría el mejor regalo que dios le podía dar, estaba embarazada.
Desde entonces la vida y sueños que tenia cambiaron para siempre, ella no pensaba cosas malas de ese embarazo, ella creía que ese embarazo le traería muchos éxitos en su vida.
Luego de que su bebe nació la relación con su familia y amigos cambio, nada es igual que antes, pero ella sabe que si las cosas pasan es por algo y que esa pequeña bebe seria el fruto de sus éxitos, sin que ella se acomplejara de ser una mama joven, decidió poner su vida en marcha, consiguió un trabajo donde allí ella pudiera darle todo a su hija y a si no dependiera de nadie.
luego de un buen tiempo se dio cuenta de que quería ser alguien en la vida y decidió estudiar administración hotelera en campo alto, desde allí todo a cambiado, a parte de trasnochar se ha dado cuenta de que es la  mejor desicion que pudo haber tomado en la vida, es algo que le gusta y es algo donde siesta aprendiendo y entendiendo lo que algún día le gustaba que eran las matemáticas, desde allí esto le ha gustado y ella sigue con muchas ganas de salir adelante que sabe que esto no es lo único que estudiaría que con tan solo 22 años sabe que la vida sigue y que hay que disfrutarla, que nada ha terminado, que la vida la llena de muchas sorpresas y sacrificios, que después de tanto luchar y luchar ella sabe que tendrá las cosas buenas que trae la vida,a aparte de que dios ya le dio el bebe y la familia por la cual luchar y salir adelante, que esto no se quedara en un técnico en hoteleria si no que seguirá hasta conseguir el mayor titulo y ser el orgullo que un día fue para la familia.
texts.en:
Yudy Tatiana is a girl whose parents were proud of her when she was little and she always liked mathematics and sports.  After finishing her bachelor’s degree she wanted to start a new life and began studying health management.  She didn’t like it because it did not involve mathematics.  Her life changed after two semesters and she learned that she would be receiving the best gift; she was pregnant.

Since then her life and dreams changed forever.  She didn’t think badly of her pregnancy, but instead believed that it would bring her lots of success in life.

After her baby was born, her relationship with her family and friends changed.  Nothing is as before, but she knows that things happen for a reason and that this small baby girl would be the future of her success without making her life difficult for being a young mother.  She decided to move ahead with her life and began working, so she could provide everything for her daughter and not have to depend on anyone.

After some time she decided to study high level hotel management.  Since then everything changed.  It’s something she enjoys and where she is learning and understanding what she enjoys; mathematics.  She likes it and has a great desire to get ahead and she knows that this will not be the only thing she studies since she is only 22 years old and she knows that life will go on and that one must enjoy it.  Life will be full of many surprises and sacrifices.  She knows that she will have all the good things in life after much hard work, aside from God having given her a baby and a family with which to get ahead.  She will not stay in the hotel industry, but will continue until getting a higher degree and being the pride or her family.

loans.use: to pay tuition.

loans.name: Rohila

texts.ru: Рохила добрая и порядочная женщина. Ей 30 лет. Она не замужем и живет с родителями. Рохила имеет высшее образование. Она бухгалтер по профессии. Рохила работает в ИМОН ИНТЕРНЕШНЛ кассиром. Рохила является одной из успешных работников. Она честно выполняет свою работу. Рохила должна поменять канализационные трубы. С такой целью она обратилась за займом. Рохила запрашивает займ на сумму 5000 сомони для покупки канализационных труб. Она ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en: Rohila is kind and decent woman. She is 30 years old. She is not married and lives with her parents. Rohila has a higher education. She is an accountant by profession. Rohila works at IMON International as a cashier. Rohila is one of the most successful employees. She does her job honestly. Rohila needs to change her sewage pipes. With this goal, she has applied for a loan. Rohila has requested a loan of 5000 Somons to buy sewer pipes. She awaits your kindness.

loans.use: To buy sewer pipes to repair the water system in her house

loans.name: Tabu

texts.en: Tabu is 44 years old, a female and married. She has four children 12, 9, 7 and 5 years old whom she supports. She was introduced to KADET Ltd by the Kadet officer. She sells milk. She has been in this business for three years. In her business, she earns a monthly income of Ksh 5,000. She is taking her third loan of Ksh 15,000, which she intends to use to buy another dairy heifer. Her previous loan of Ksh 15,000 was paid back successfully. Tabu will use the anticipated profit to expand her business. Her hopes and dreams for her future are to grow her business and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase another dairy heifer for milk production.

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
A $600 loan is offered to Aurelia to improve her business. She has a kiosk where many people come to buy products every day. She will buy some additional supplies such as noodles, fish, cigarettes, coffee, sugar, salt, bread, and shampoo with the loan. 

She has been involving herself in business activities since 2002. She feels comfortable running her business because she can earn money every day.
Running a business has made Aurelia independent because she can be responsible for herself and also help her family. She hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy noodles, fish, cigarettes, coffee, sugar, salt, bread, and shampoo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to expand her business.

loans.name: Christopher's Group

texts.en:
Christopher is a member of the Baraka Group in Webuye District.  He is pictured here in a group of nine One Acre Fund group leader farmers.  The group leaders represent a total of 83 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  

Christopher has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with his hand raised.  He and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of KES 5,349 for maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation.							

Christopher is married and has seven children.  He is 69 years old and is known as friendly, hardworking, reliable, trustworthy, and an experienced farmer.  He is active in his community in groups such as the men's group, savings group, prayer group, and burial committee.  

Christopher has been a farmer for 39 years.  He described his harvest as excellent last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.  							

Christopher joined One Acre Fund in 2009, and he is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2014 season as a group leader.  Christopher joined One Acre Fund so that he could get the best seed prices, get new farming methods, get fertilizer and hybrid seeds, earn enough to feed his family, and send his children to school.  He also became a group leader because he likes being a leader, is an active community member, wants to help more farmers, and wants to spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers.  

Working with One Acre Fund has improved Christopher's life because he has more profits from harvest, has more farm training, has more farm group support, was able to save money, and was able to feed his family.  In the future, Christopher hopes that his profits from 2014 can be used to send his children to school, repair his home, save for the future, buy a cow, and invest in a business.  

Christopher and the Baraka Group Group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  

Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits, and improved lives.							
		
Please note that there is one additional group leader in this photo who will be working with One Acre Fund but will not be a part of this Kiva group loan.

The field officer is also included in the photo.

loans.use: To buy cost-efficient maize, millet, and sorghum seeds.

loans.name: Hudson's Group

texts.en:
Hudson is a member of Green Garden Group in Webuye District. He is pictured here in a group of 9 One Acre Fund group leader farmers.  The group leaders represent a total of 103 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  Hudson has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with his hand raised.  He and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation.

Hudson is married and has 9 children.  He is 54 years old and is known as friendly, hardworking, reliable, trustworthy, and an experienced farmer.  He is active in his community in groups such as the men's group, and savings group, and prayer group, and burial committee. Hudson has been a farmer for 16 years. Hudson described his harvest as good last year, but he believes he can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.  							
			
Hudson first enrolled with One Acre Fund in 2011 and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2014 Long Rains season. Hudson joined One Acre Fund in order to get the best seed prices, get new farming methods, get fertilizer and hybrid seeds, earn enough to feed family, and send his children to school. He also volunteered to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he is an active community member, he wants to help more farmers, and wants to spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers. Hudson plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send the children to school, repair the home, save for the future, and buy a goat. He notes that working with One Acre Fund has lead to many benefits for One Acre Fund farmers. Hudson’s own life was improved because he has more profits from harvest, has more farm training and support, and was able to save money and feed his family.  

Hudson and the Green Garden Group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund. One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests. One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers. Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund. With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits, and improved lives.
		
The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To provide Kenyan farmers with increased access to hybrid seeds and fertilizer for harvesting maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more dry and fresh fish for her business.

loans.name: Franklin

texts.en: Franklin is 55 years old, a male and married. He has two (2) children, 20 and 14 years old, respectively, whom he supports. He was introduced to KADET Ltd by a Kadet officer and he has a tailoring shop which has lasted for nine years now. It is located in Mjanaheri. In his business he earns a monthly income of 3,550 KES. He is taking out his first loan of 5,000 KES, which he intends to use to add stock to his business by buying more materials. Franklin will use the anticipated profits to expand his business. His hopes and dreams for his future business and family are to expand his tailoring shop and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more materials to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Rosa Magdalena

texts.es:
La Señora. Rosa forma parte del grupo de crédito Las Cuencanitas desde hace 4 años, en todo este tiempo ha llegado a establecer una muy buena amistad con todas las socias. Vive en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es reconocida por su belleza natural, arquitectónica y cultural, es cuna de grandes Deportistas, escritores y sobre todo de gente muy amable.
La Señora. Rosa tiene 59 años de edad, es madre soltera y ha concebido 4 hijos a quienes les ha sacado adelante con su sacrificio, ellos son mayores de edad, están casados y viven  independientes, no tiene casa propia por lo que vive arrendando.
Doña Rosa lleva muchos años en el negocio de venta de frutas, no tiene puesto propio por lo que vende ambulantemente. 
El dinero de su crédito va a invertir en la compra de frutas de temporada. Su meta es  crecer en el negocio.
texts.en:
Señora Rosa has been a member of the loan group Las Cuencanitas [The little Ladies from Cuenca] for 4 years. During this time she has come to establish a very good friendship with all of the members. She lives in the city of Cuenca, which known for its natural, architectural, and cultural beauty. It is home to great athletes, writers, and above all, very nice people.

Señora Rosa is 59 years old, and a single mother of 4 children, whom she has raised by making sacrifices.  Now they are adults, married, and living independently. She does not own her own home so she rents.

Doña Rosa has been in the business of selling fruit for many years. She does not have her own stall so she makes her sales on foot. She is going to invest the money from her loan in purchasing seasonal fruits. Her goal is to grow in the business.

loans.use: to purchase fruit.

loans.name: Marfina

texts.en:
A $1,000 loan is offered to Marfina to improve her business. She is married and has three children. She is living in a town with her family.

Marfina opened her kiosk in 2009 with her own working capital. She will use the loan to buy stock to keep in her store like oil, water, noodles, cigarettes and rice. 

She is generating a good income from selling. She has been thinking of running a big business after years of involving herself in doing business.

loans.use: to buy oil, water, noodles, cigarettes and rice.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more dry and fresh fish to resell.

loans.name: Andrew's Group

texts.en:
Andrew is a member of Bulala Group in Chwele District. He is pictured here in a group of 8 One Acre Fund group leader farmers. The group leaders represent a total of 72 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here. Andrew has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with his hand raised. He and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet. Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 Kenyan shillings for maize, millet and sorghum cultivation.							

Andrew is 70 years old and has been a farmer for 40 years.  Andrew works as a farmer to provide for his 9 children. The community and other farmers know Andrew as friendly, hardworking and trustworthy. Other than farming, he is also involved in activities in his community such as the men's group.  Andrew described his harvest last year as excellent, but he hopes he can have an even better one with the support of One Acre Fund and the other farmers in her group.							

Andrew first enrolled with One Acre Fund in 2011 and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2014 Long Rains season.  Andrew joined One Acre Fund in order to get new farming methods, earn enough to feed family, earn enough to feed the family and send the children to school. He also volunteered to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he wants to help more One Acre Fund farmers. Andrew plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school, buy a cow and invest in a business. He notes that working with One Acre Fund has lead to many benefits for One Acre Fund farmers. Andrew’s own life was improved because he was able to save money and feed the family.  			

Andrew and the Bulala Group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund. One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests. One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers. Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund. With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.						

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Christine's Group

texts.en:
Christine’s group has 8 farmers and is located in Chwele District.  The group leaders in this group represent a total of 70 individual farmers (not pictured) who are each asking for an average loan of 5,349 shillings to purchase a One Acre Fund package for ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  As the Kiva group representative, Christine is pictured on the right of the Namirembe Group with her hand raised.	
					
Christine is married and has 6 children.  She is 34 years old and is known as a hardworking and an experienced farmer.  She is active in her community activities in groups such as the Women's Group and Savings Group.  Christine has been a farmer for 13 years.  Christine described her harvest as excellent last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.  

Christine joined One Acre Fund in 2011, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2014 season as a group leader.  Christine joined One Acre Fund so that she could get the best seed prices, get fertilizer and hybrid seeds, earn enough to feed her family and send her children to school. Because she wants to help more farmers, Christine has gotten more involved with One Acre Fund as a group leader and Kiva representative.  Working with One Acre Fund has improved Christine's life because she has more profits from the harvest and was able to feed her family.  In the future, Christine hopes that her profits from 2014 can be used to send her children to school.  							

Christine and the Namirembe Group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.

loans.use: To allow farmers the opportunity to buy cost efficient maize, millet, and sorghum seeds.

loans.name: Agnes' Group

texts.en:
Agnes is a member of the Bidii Group in Chwele District.  She is pictured here in a group of four One Acre Fund group leader farmers.  The group leaders represent a total of 48 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  

Agnes has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with her hand raised.  She and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of KES 5,349 for maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation.							

Agnes is 44 years old and has been a farmer for 10 years.  She works as a farmer to provide for her six children.  The community and other farmers know Agnes as hardworking and trustworthy.  Other than farming, she is also involved in her community activities such as the women's group.  Agnes described her harvest last year as excellent, but hopes she can have an even better one with the support of One Acre Fund and the other farmers in her group.
							
The 2013 Long Rains season won’t be Agnes’s first season with One Acre Fund.  She first joined One Acre Fund in 2010 and has continued working with One Acre Fund in order to get new farming methods.  

Agnes also chose to be a group leader and Kiva representative because she is an active community member.  Agnes plans on using future profits from the harvest to send hr children to school and buy a cow.  Her life has improved by working with One Acre Fund because she has more farm group support, is able to save money, and feed her family.

Agnes and the Bidii Group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  

Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits, and improved lives.

The field officer is also included in the photo, standing on the left.

loans.use: to buy cost-efficient maize, millet, and sorghum seeds.

loans.name: Poniyara

texts.en:
Poniyara is 30 years old, married, and together with her husband, is raising three sons.  All their sons are receiving education and they are in class VIII (Grade 8), class VII (Grade 7) and class IV( Grade 4). Poniyara is illiterate and can only sign her name. Her husband Sofiyar is 42 years old and he is also uneducated, can sign his name only. They live in the small village of East Magurmari in Dhupguri in the district Jalpaiguri. Poniyara is a housewife and does household work and looks after her husband and sons. They live in their own kachha house( mud, straw and bamboo-made).

Poniyara's husband is engaged in a milk supply business.  They have a cow.  He supplies milk from door to door in their locality. Unfortunately his income is not enough to provide all of their family's needs, which is why Poniyara has decided to help her husband.

She has come to know about Kiva’s partner, BJS, and has decided to take a loan from them, which will enable her to buy a cow.  She wants to start a dairy products business (products like paneer i.e., fresh cheese, butter, curd, etc.) beside milk supply.  The products have great demand in the present market, so she hopes it will be a profitable business. Moreover, she can sell the cow dung which is used as good manure in the rural areas in their locality, which will also increase their income.

Her dreams are to use her earnings in the further acquisition of livestock, better education for her sons, to meet the family's financial needs and upgrade their kachha house to a pacca house (concrete-made).

She is thankful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase a cow to start a dairy products business.

loans.name: Geeta

texts.en:
Geeta is a housewife from a small village Kalirhat in Dhupguri in the district Jalpaiguri.  She is 34 years old and attended school up to class VIII (Grade 8). She lives with her husband and only daughter aged 17 years.  They have a small semi-pacca house (brick-built with a straw roof). Her daughter is a student in class twelve (Grade 12). Her husband Ratan, who is 38 years old, is a farmer.  He completed his primary education.  He is engaged in agriculture, but due to lack of capital, he cannot invest much money in his business.  He is the main breadwinner of the family and works hard to be able to make ends meet.  Yet he is unable to give enough financial sustenance to the family.

Geeta is determined to help her husband by providing financial assistance. So she has decided to take a loan from Kiva’s partner BJS, who gives loans to rural women, to buy potato seeds and fertilizers to start a potato cultivation business in their own plot of land. She is very energetic and enthusiastic and hopes to earn profits by selling the produce in the local market.  It is a profitable business as the produce has a good demand in the present market.

Geeta's goals are to upgrade the financial condition of their family, give her daughter a good future, and enhance the business to secure their future.  She dreams of building a pacca house (concrete-made) of their own with the profits from the business.

Geeta and her family will be thankful to both BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase potato seeds and fertilizers for starting cultivation of potatoes.

loans.name: Nercita

texts.en:
Nercita is married with two children. She is 54 years old and lives in Segatic Diot, Clarin, Philippines. Nercita sells a variety of goods to earn a living and has had this business for seven years. Each month, she earns 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 50,000 PHP to restock her store with basic commodities.

Nercita has been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for one year. In the future, Nercita hopes to put up another profitable business.

loans.use: to restock her store with basic commodities

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa is 40 years old and lives in Colambutan Settlement, Tudela. She is married with six children. To earn a living, Elisa has a business selling vegetables in the local market. She earns about 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) each month doing this type of work. Elisa has requested a loan to restock her store with more vegetables to sell.

Elisa has been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for four years. Elisa would like to save for future consumption.

loans.use: to restock her store with more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Ma.lorena

texts.en: Ma. Lorena is 37 years old. She is single and she lives in Poblacion Sibutad Zamboanga del Norte. She has engaged in her sari-sari store business for 2 years and earned a monthly income of 2000. She is asking for a loan to buy additional inventory for her store. She hopes to save for her retirement.

loans.use: to buy additional inventory for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta is taking a loan of $1,000 to improve her business. She is single. She is running a kiosk that helps her to generate income for her family. 

She will use the loan to buy stock to keep in her store, such as noodles, sugar, salt, cigarettes and coconut oil. 

She opened her kiosk a year ago with her own working capital of $500. She is a hardworking woman, and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy noodles, sugar, salt, cigarettes and coconut oil.

loans.name: Jyotsna

texts.en:
Jyotsna, 30 years old, is from the small village of West Magurmari in Dhupguri in the district Jalpaiguri. She is married to Karunakanta, who is 37 years old.  She lives with her husband and three children (one son, two daughters) in their own kachha house (mud, straw and bamboo-made).  Both Jyotsna and her husband received education up to class VI (Grade 6). Her three children are receiving education in class VIII (Grade 8), class VI (Grade 6) and class II ( Grade 2) respectively .

Jyotsna 's husband is engaged in agricultural work.  He has been associated with agricultural activities for many years.  He produces beans, onions and other vegetables for the family's consumption and to sell in the local market.  Jyotsna is a housewife.  She manages the household work and, at the same time, helps her husband in the agricultural activities.  Her husband's earnings are hardly enough to cover food and household expenses for the family. Jyotsna decided to grow potatoes in their land and sell them at the local bazaar, since potatoes are in great demand in the present market.  She hopes she will be able to increase the family funds through potato cultivation.

As soon as she heard about BJS (Kiva’s partner), Jyotsna applied for a loan to help her husband to buy good quality potato seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: To purchase seeds of potatoes for cultivation.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es:
Carlos es soltero, de 27 años de edad, tiene 3 hijos todos menores de edad y estudiantes, el junto a su familia vive en Cantón Xajaxac, Sololá. Se dedica a la agricultura (cultivo de papa, arveja  y zanahoria), lleva 10 años en esta labor, la cual heredó de sus padres. Realiza está actividad porque le gusta y es la fuente de sus ingresos que utiliza para el sostenimiento sus hijos. 
El está solicitando un préstamo de Q 2,000.00 para la compra de semilla y fertilizante orgánico y pago de mano de obra para el cultivo de arveja. 
Sueña con mejorar su vivienda para darle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Carlos, 27, is single and has three children who are in school. He lives with his family in Cantón Xajaxac, Sololá. He works as a farmer by harvesting potatoes, peas, and carrots. He has done this work for 10 years, which he inherited from his parents. He does this work because he enjoys it and he can use the income to support his family.

He is requesting this loan of 2,000 QTG to buy seeds and fertilizer and to pay workers to harvest peas.

He dreams of improving his home to give his family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer and to pay workers to harvest peas.

loans.name: Lovella

texts.en: Lovella is 41 years old. She is married and and has 4 children, She lives in Poblacion Sibutad, Zamboanga del Norte. Her husband is a carpenter. Lovella has engaged in her sari-sari store business for 13 years and earned a monthly income of 3500. She applied for a loan to buy stock for her sari-sari store. She has been a CUMI member of Paglaum MPC since 2012. She is striving hard for her children's future.

loans.use: to buy stock for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Makuti A Group

texts.en:
Mariamu, who is in her mid 40s, is divorced, with one school kid and two grown chidren. 

For five years now, Mariamu has been involved with her food business (a restaurant). She is also owns a room that she rents to people for a living. Mariamu works from 5 a.m. to 6 p.m. per working day and is able to make a nice profit. 

This will be her first loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania, which she will use to buy new serving dishes for her food business and new clothes for selling. Mariamu dreams of being an international business person. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "Makuti A," which totals five members. The members of the group will hold one another accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy new serving dishes for her food business and new clothes for selling.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is a 46 year old woman from the town of Maribojoc, Bohol. She is married and runs a variety store. She sells basic commodities like eggs, cooking oil, biscuits, coffee and toiletries. Her business started quite a few years ago. She is asking for a loan to buy additional stock for the store like noodles, beverages, soap, seasonings, and  canned goods to maintain the inventory of her store.

In the future, Lorna  hopes to expand her business to improve her livelihood status.

loans.use: to buy additional stock for her store

loans.name: Mandzano's Group

texts.en:
This group of four people is part of a group called "Mandzano" that was established in November 2010. It is made up of members who are on very good terms. There is a good complicity among them, and they really stand together. Their main business is the retail of commodities like cosmetics, slippers and smoked fish. They need 4,200 GHS.

Dora is the woman standing in the middle of the two ladies in the photograph. She is 42 years old, married, and the mother of two boys and one girl. Her business consists in selling cosmetics.

She intends to buy more cosmetics with 1,600 GHS, which could fetch her a profit of 200 GHS in two weeks.

She will use her profits to bolster her savings, and also to help her husband cover the expenses of the household (children's education and food).

loans.use: to buy more cosmetics for re-sale.

loans.name: Kashutu

texts.en:
Kashutu is 63 years old and married. She has two children, 20 and 18 years, whom she supports. 

Kashutu runs a grocery business, which has lasted for six years now. It is located at Kijiwetanga.

She earns a monthly income of KES 700. She was introduced to KADET Ltd by a Kadet officer.

She is taking a fourth loan from Kadet of KES 20,000, which she intends to use to buy more vegetables. Her previous loan of KES 10,000 she paid back to KADET successfully. 

She will use the anticipated profit to expand her business by making it to be a wholesale business. 

Her hopes and dreams for her future business are to open another grocery business and also to make sure her children get better education and have a brighter future.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Laxmi is a homemaker and lives in their own small semi-kachha house( brick-built and thatched roof) with her husband Jagabondhu and their two children (one son and one daughter). Laxmi is illiterate and can only sign her name.  Her husband completed secondary education.  They live in the small village of Modhya Khagrabari in the district Jalpaiguri. They can hardly afford the educational expenses of their daughter, who is in class III (Grade 3). Their son is below school-going age.

Laxmi's husband is engaged in cultivation of potatoes in their small plot of land and sells the produce in their local market.  His agricultural business is the only source of income for the family.

As life is getting more expensive over time, Laxmi needs to help her husband to expand the business. So she applied for a loan from BJS to purchase potato seeds and fertilizers. The demand for potatoes is very high in the local market.

She hopes this will give them more income to improve their quality of life and help cover her children's education. In future they want to buy another piece of land with the profit generated from the business.

Her full thanks go to BJS as well as to Kiva for giving her the loan.

loans.use: To purchase potato seeds for cultivation of potatoes.

loans.name: Leonard's Group

texts.en:
Leonard is a member of Alala Group in Webuye District.  He is pictured here in a group of 9 One Acre Fund group leader farmers.  The group leaders represent a total of 85 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  Leonard has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with his hand raised.  He and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation.							

Leonard is married and has 6 children.  He is 41 years old and is known as friendly, hardworking, reliable and an experienced farmer.  He is active in his community in groups such as the men's group, savings group, prayer group and burial committee.  Leonard has been a farmer for 25 years.  He described his harvest as excellent last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund     							.

The 2013 Long Rains season won’t be Leonard’s first season with One Acre Fund.  He first joined One Acre Fund in 2012 and has continued working with One Acre Fund in order to get the best seed prices, new farming methods, fertilizer and hybrid seeds.  He also wants to earn enough to feed his family and send his children to school.  As an active member in his community, Leonard also chose to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he is an active community member.  He wants to help more farmers and wants to spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers.  Leonard plans on using future profits from the harvest to send his children to school, repair his home, save for the future, buy a goat and invest in a business.  His life has improved by working with One Acre Fund because he has more profits from harvests and is able to save money.  He has more farm training and farm group support.					

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya.  The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers.  Leonard and the Alala Group will use the Kiva loan to cover this initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund continues providing training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.		

Please note that there is 1 additional group leader in this photo who will be working with One Acre Fund but will not be a part of this Kiva group loan.

loans.use: To allow farmers the opportunity to buy cost efficient maize, millet, and sorghum seeds.

loans.name: Archana

texts.en:
Archana is a 50-year-old woman who is married and has three daughters. She is from the rural area of Maynaguri in the district Jalpaiguri. She is uneducated and can only sign her name. Her husband Asit is 57 years old and a farmer by trade. He completed higher secondary education (Grade 12). Two of their daughters are receiving an education.  They are studying in class VII ( Grade 8) and class X (Grade 10).  The eldest daughter is married. They live in their own small kachha house (mud, straw and bamboo-made).

Archana's husband grows different vegetables in different seasons and sells those vegetable in the local market and earns money to cover the needs of the family. His income is too low to meet all the needs of the family. They provide education to their daughters with great difficulty.

Archana has decided to stretch her helping hands to her husband.  She came to know about Kiva’s partner, BJS, and decided to take a loan to start a business of tailoring. She wants to buy a sewing machine to start a business of tailoring in her locality.  She stitches different types of garments and sells them to the local garment shops.  She has three years of experience with this business and she used to run a tailoring shop before her marriage. So, she hopes that the business will be a fruitful one and will serve her purposes.

Her dreams are to give their daughters better education, betterment of the financial condition of their family, and to enhance the business further.

She is grateful to BJS as well as Kiva for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine to start a tailoring business.

loans.name: Elmar

texts.en: Elmar is 32 years old, married, and has two children. He is raising his family in a rural community and makes their living through farming. To have another source of income, he engages in a hog-raising business. He aims to improve his family's status of living in order to satisfy their necessities and give their children a better life. He plans to acquire more pigs to raise but he has limited capital. For this reason, he is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy hog feeds, vitamins, and additional pigs to raise. He believes that his loan will enable him to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy hog feeds, vitamins, and additional pigs to raise

loans.name: Kakakuona Group

texts.en:
Hadija is single and has five daughters; two of them are still at school and the rest are grown-ups. Since 1999, she has been running a business of selling fish from door to door. She also has a house for renting, where she collects money after every six months. She works at her fish business from 6am to 1pm daily, and is able to get a small monthly profit.  

This will be Hadija's 10th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to build her rental house and bought more stock of fish to meet her customers' demand. She has paid back all her loans successfully. She used the profit to pay school fees, covered household expenses, bought a fridge, a TV set, a cupboard, chairs and a bed. She is doing great and is happy with a loan. She will use this loan to buy wood and iron sheets to finish building another room for her rental house. She dreams of expanding her fish business.

Hadija will share this loan with her loan group "Kakakuona" which has ten members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy wood and iron sheets to finish building another room for her rental house.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: An $800 loan is offered to Juliana to improve her business. She is married and she has three children, and is living in a town with her family. She opened her mini shop in 2000 with her own working capital of $100. She will use the loan to buy stocks to keep in her store like trousers, shorts, long sleeve and short sleeve shirts, and children's wear. She is generating a good income from selling her things from the mini shop. After years of doing this business, she is interested in running a bigger business.

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a single mother of four children, and all her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. 

She has a bakery business, which she has been in for ten years. She has applied for a loan of 700,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more cooking oil, baking flour, cheese and butter. She works from home seven days out of every week. Her major business challenges include seasonality and the ever increasing prices of cooking oil and baking flour.

Florence aspires of owning a big bakery and also of becoming a supplier. She decided to join MCDT-SACCO because of good customer care. She lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees.

loans.use: to buy more cooking oil, baking flour, cheese and butter.

loans.name: Mt Meru Group

texts.en:
Sabina, who is single, is running a business of sarongs and fabrics for two years now. She is in her early 40s. Sabina works from 8am to 9pm and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Sabina's 9th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy more fabrics and sarongs and has paid back all her loans successfully.  She used the profit to cover household expenses and bought a plot of land. She will use this loan to buy more new babies' and adult clothing and shoes to sell in the coming Christmas holiday season. She dreams of owning a wholesale shop.

She will share this loan with her loan group, "Mt Meru", which has a total of four members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more new babies' and adult clothing and shoes to sell in the coming Christmas holiday season.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a widow with six children, five of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren). She has a business of selling milk and has been in this business for 6 years. She has applied for a loan of 700,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more milk and bread to sell.  She generates additional income from rental rooms.  

She works in a shop and sells on a retail basis only.  Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves.  She is aspiring of owning a fully stocked milk (dairy) shop. She decided to join MCDT-SACCO because she wanted to get additional income.  She resides in the family house and has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more milk and bread to sell.

loans.name: Sumayiya

texts.en:
Sumayiya is married with four children, and all her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has a business of selling used clothes and has been in this business for 5 years. 

She has applied for a loan of 800,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bales of used clothes.  She generates additional income from rental rooms.  She moves door to door selling used clothes and sells on a retail basis six days out of every week.  Her major business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. 

She is aspiring of getting a permanent business premises and also to become a wholesaler. She decided to join MCDT-SACCO because of good customer care. She resides in the family house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothes.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is married, with two children, and one of her children goes to school.  She doesn’t have additional family members to take care of.

She has a business, a restaurant, and has been in this business for two years. She has applied for a loan of UGX 500,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy more foodstuffs like bunches of green bananas, beef, rice, and sweet potatoes.   

She works from home seven days out of every week and sells on a retail basis. She generates additional income from selling tomatoes. Her major business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. 

She aspires to own a fully stocked restaurant and also to buy a plot of land and build a house. She decided to join MCDT-SACCO because of low interest charged.  

She resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity but not to piped water . Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs like bunches of green bananas, beef, rice, and sweet potatoes

loans.name: Bailey

texts.en:
Bailey is married with three children, two of whom go to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members.  

She has a business of a pub, and has been in this business for four years. She has applied for a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings to buy more crates of beer, soda and spirits. Bailey works six days out of every week and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves. She aspires of becoming a wholesaler and also hopes to educate her children up to university. 

Bailey decided to join MCDTSACCO  because she wanted to acquire more capital. She resides in the family house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes rent for her business premises and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer, soda and spirits.

loans.name: Roderick's Group

texts.en:
Action is a group of 9 group leader farmers in Webuye District with Roderick selected as the Kiva representative.  Roderick has volunteered to be the Kiva group representative and is on the right of the photo with his hand raised.  Farming inputs will be delivered to him and the 81 other individual farmers represented in this group.  The credit consists of the necessary materials to plant ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of millet or sorghum.  The individual farmers are not pictured here but will be receiving an average loan of 5,349 shillings.

Roderick is married and has 18 children.  He is 74 years old and is known as friendly, hardworking, reliable, trustworthy and an experienced farmer.  He is active in his community in groups such as the men's group, savings group, prayer group and burial committee.  Roderick has been a farmer for 41 years.  Roderick described his harvest as good last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. 

The 2013 Long Rains season won’t be Roderick’s first season with One Acre Fund.  He first joined One Acre Fund in 2012 and has continued working with One Acre Fund in order to get the best seed prices, new farming methods, fertilizer and hybrid seeds.  He also wants to earn enough to feed his family and send his children to school.  As an active member in his community, Roderick also chose to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he is an active community member, and he wants to help more farmers.  He wants to spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers.  Roderick plans on using future profits from the harvest to send his children to school, repair their home, save for the future, buy a goat and invest in a business.  His life has improved by working with One Acre Fund because he has more profits from harvests and is able to save money.  He also has more farm training and group support through this program. 

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya.  The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers.  Roderick and the Action Group will use the Kiva loan to cover this initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund continues providing training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.

Please note that there is 1 additional group leader in this photo who will be working with One Acre Fund but will not be a part of this Kiva group loan.

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To provide Kenyan farmers with increased access to hybrid seed and fertilizer for harvesting maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Onua-Do Group

texts.en:
These five members are part of a group called 'onua-do' who all live in the same neighborhood and work together whenever the need arises. Samuel is their representative and can be seen in the photo standing on the right. 

Samuel is a married father with two children who has more than ten years experience in selling men's shirts. He is responsible for his family which consists of his children and his wife.

Samuel will use his loan share of GHS 1,500 to buy more men's ready-made clothing to sell to his customers. He starts his working day at 8am and finishes at 5pm. 

In the future, he would like to use further loans from this field partner to grow his business and increase his earnings. In this way, he could improve the living conditions of his immediate family.

This group would need a total amount of GHS 5,600 to buy more ready-mades, fruits and vegetables, wigs, creams, provisions and slippers.

loans.use: To buy more men's ready-made clothing to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Ekome Feemo's Group

texts.en:
Mary, who is in her mid 50s, is a widow with four grown up children who are living on their own. She has been selling smoked fish for the past twenty years. She works from 7am to 5pm daily, and is able to make a very good monthly profit. 

This will be Mary's seventh loan from ID-Ghana. She used the previous loans to buy more fish to smoke and sell to customers. She has been very successful and happy with the loans. Mary gives thanks to all who have supported her 'Ekome Feemo' group. She has successfully repaid all her loans. She used the profit to reinvest into her business.

Mary will share this loan amount of GHS 3500 with her loan group members who will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan.

loans.use: to buy more fish to smoke and sell to customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more oil, rice and pepper, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a single mother of two children, and both of her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (old parents). 

She has a business selling used clothes from door to door, to all categories of people, but on a retail basis. She has applied for a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bales of used clothes. 

Fatuma generates additional income from a canteen and sells on a retail basis six days out of every week. Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves who always meet her on her way. She aspires of getting a permanent business premises and also of buying another plot of land. She decided to join MCDT-SACCO because it was near her home. She lives in her own house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bales of used clothes to sell.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a single mother of four children and all her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has a business of selling used handbags and has been in this business for 15 years. 

She has applied for a loan of 1,000,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bales of used bags.  She works in a shop seven days out of every week and sells on both a retail and a wholesale basis. Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves.

Ruth is aspiring of selling on a wholesale basis only and also to start importing used clothes. She decided to join MCDT-SACCO because she wanted a timely loan.  She resides in the family house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used handbags.

loans.name: Dúo Las Victorias Group

texts.es:
DUO LAS VICTORIAS
Doña Santa Victoria es originaria de la Aldea Xetzac municipio de Tecpán Guatemala, ella tiene 43 años de edad, bajo su responsabilidad están sus tres hijos menores de edad, ella se dedica a la fabricación y venta de suéteres.
Desde hace años ella empezó su propio negocio y gracias a Dios ahora a crecido bastante, ahora ya tiene otras maquinas y ya puede hacer diferentes estilos de suéteres.
Gracias al apoyo de su esposo y el de sus hijos ella sigue adelante con su trabajo.
El crédito que ella recibió lo utilizo para invertirlo en materia prima, para poder fabricar sus suéteres ya que ahora por la época de fin de año le hacen pedidos por docena.
El sueño de ella es ampliar mas su negocio, ofrecer mas estilos de suéteres a sus clientes, ya que asi tendrá mejores ganancias, y poder mandar a sus hijos a estudiar a un colegio ya que hoy en dia es muy importante que los hijos se preparen académicamente para un futuro mejor.
texts.en:
LAS VICTORIAS DUO

Santa Victoria is from the Xetzac village in the municipality of Tecpán, Guatemala. She is 43 years old and has three children in her care. She makes a living by making and selling sweaters. Years ago she started her own business, and thanks to God it has now grown quite a bit. She now has other machines and is able to make various styles of sweaters. Thanks to the support of her husband and that of her children, she keeps moving ahead with her work.

She used the loan that she received to invest in raw material to be able to make her sweaters, as now at the end of the year she gets requests by the dozen. Her dream is to expand her business more and to offer more styles of sweaters to her customers. That way she will have better earnings and will be able to send her children to study at a high school, as nowadays it is very important that children prepare themselves academically for a better future.

loans.use: to buy raw materials to make sweaters

loans.name: Rosette

texts.en:
Rosette is a single mother of three children, all of whom go to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members.  

Rosette has been operating a retail shop for the past three years. She works in the shop seven days out of every week. Her major business challenges include stiff competition, transportation and the ever increasing prices of commodities. She has applied for a loan of 400,000 UGX from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of sugar, rice and boxes of soap.   

She aspires of owning a delivery van to ease her transportation and also to own a fully stocked retail shop. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bags of sugar, rice and boxes of soap to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a widow with four children, and two of her children go to school.  She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has a business of selling tomatoes and onions and has been in this business for 10 years. 

She has applied for a loan of 500,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more boxes of tomatoes and onions. She works at the market seven days out of every week and sells on a retail basis.  Her major business challenges include seasonality and perishability. 

Rose is aspiring of becoming a wholesaler and also to start growing those vegetables. She resides in the family house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees and paying utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of tomatoes and onions.

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy is a single mother of four children, all of whom go to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. 

She has a business of a mini bakery, and has been in this business for ten years. She works from home six days out of every week, and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves. Teddy has applied for a loan of 300,000 UGX from MCDT-SACCO to buy more cooking oil, baking flour, cowpeas and baking powder for her business.  

Teddy aspires of owning a big bakery and also hopes to educate her children up to university. She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more cooking oil, baking flour, cowpeas and baking powder.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more palm oil for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase breakable dishes such as plates, bowls, glasses, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Hekuran

texts.en:
Hekuran is a 46-year-old married Egyptian Albanian man who has been working in the construction industry for about six years now. Working mostly as a painter in his hometown where the majority of his community lives, he also offers services to everyone and not only to his own people. He has three children; the oldest is 19 and the youngest is 8.
 
The loan of 250,000 Albanian Lek that he is requesting for the first time will be used to buy items and tools needed in his profession, such as plaster, paints, gypsum, etc.

loans.use: to buy items used in his profession, such as plaster, paints, gypsum, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more slippers for her business.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a single mother of six children, and all of her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. 

She has a business selling foodstuffs such as Irish potatoes, cassava, sweet potatoes, cabbages and onions. She works at the market and sells on a retail basis seven days out of every week. Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves. Betty has applied for a loan of 300,000 UGX from MCDT-SACCO to buy more cabbages, onions, cassava, sweet and Irish potatoes. 

Betty aspires of growing some of those foodstuffs and also of becoming a wholesaler and to buy a plot of land. She lives in the family house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more cabbages, onions, sweet potatoes, cassava and Irish potatoes.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is 44 years old and married. She is from Maribojoc, Bohol. She weaves nipa palm, which is commonly used as roofing on native houses in the Philippines. She has been in the nipa business for a number of years. 

Marilou is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy more nipa palm. With the loan, she will produce more and earn a higher income. In the future, Marilou hopes to expand her nipa weaving business and increase business profitability to improve her livelihood status.

loans.use: to purchase nipa palm

loans.name: Sajama 27 Group

texts.es: El banco de emprendimiento SAJAMA 27, está compuesto por ocho integrantes siete mujeres y un  varón,  todas ellas se dedican a distintas actividades, la presidenta del banco es la señora Cristina tiene 60 años casada con dos  hijos ya mayores de edad, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa para mujeres de pollera, ella vende sus productos en distintas ferias de la ciudad de El Alto, este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución, la señora Cristina,  va a usar este préstamo para compra de ropa al por mayor y así surtir su negocio, su razón para solicitar este préstamo es incrementar su mercadería, la señora Cristina enfrenta retos en su negocio que son la competencia y va a utilizar los beneficios en seguir comprando  mercadería y así de esta manera genera más ingresos económicos, se siente feliz ya agradecida por ella y por sus compañeras de grupo ya que en muchos caso sacan solas adelante a su familias.
texts.en:
The Sajama 27 entrepreneurship bank is formed by eight members, seven women and one man. They make a living from a variety of businesses. The president of the bank is Cristina, who is 60 years old and married with two children who are already grown. She makes a living by selling traditional clothing for women. She sells her products at various markets in the city of El Alto.

This loan is her first sequence in the institution. Cristina is going to use this loan to buy clothing wholesale and thus stock her business. Her motivation for asking for this loan is to increase her merchandise. Cristina faces challenges in her business, such as competition, and she is going to use her profits to keep buying merchandise. In this way she will generate more financial earnings. She feels happy and grateful for this and for her fellow group members, as in many cases people have to get their families ahead on their own.

loans.use: to buy traditional clothing for women wholesale

loans.name: Kasi Mpya 1 Group

texts.en:
Yunis, who is in her late 40s, is married with two girls and two boys, who are in school. 

She has been running a business of selling two types of clothes.  She has sold new clothes and second-hand clothes for 15 years now.  She works from 7 a.m. to 8:30 p.m. daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Yunis's third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase her stock of both types of clothes. She is hard working and it shows!  She has paid back all her loans successfully.  

She used the profit to pay school fees, cover household expenses, and buy a TV set, a sofa set, and a fridge.  

She will use this loan to buy more new clothes to meet her customers' demand.  She dreams of building a house for renting.

Yunis will share this loan with her loan group "Kasi Mpya 1," with two members who hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more new clothes to meet her customers' demand.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah works hard to support her six children. She is married, and she has a general store business in the Philippines.

Leah has requested a PHP 4,600 loan through NWTF to buy a solar lamp.

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to provide her children with bright light when they study at night.

Leah is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is not only saving money.  She is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase a solar lamp

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase oil, onions, pepper, rice, charcoal and salt, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Mandle's Group

texts.en:
"Mandle" is a Community group that has 11 members. They sell plastic products, sugar cane, maize, cassava, plantains, shoes and gari (cassava flour).

Rita is 31 years old and the group representative. She is married and has three dependable children. Like the other members of this group, Rita is a successful seller of cassava, plantain and gari. She has had three successful loan cycles with ID-Ghana, and she has been able to help her family. 

The loan she is requesting will be invested in cassava, plantain and gari so that she can serve her customers better. In the future, she would like to buy a house where she can live peacefully with her family. 

Rita would like to thank the Kiva lenders for accepting to help her group since it is an opportunity for them to improve their incomes.They need a total amount of 6,550 GHS to improve their businesses.

loans.use: to invest in cassava, plantains and gari so that she can better serve her customers.

loans.name: El Sol Sale Para Todos 4 & 6 Group

texts.en:
Marina is the coordinator of her group, El Sol Sale Para Todos 4 & 6. She makes her home in a simple structure with her husband. She says that her most difficult challenge right now is improving her business. In the meantime, she plans to continue spending time with her family.

Marina is excited to be taking out her 8th loan with Esperanza. She has had her business for more than five years, and started her business with some savings. She plans to use this loan to invest in her fried chicken restaurant by buying potatoes, plantains, cooking oil, chicken, disposable dishes, and other goods. She will use the profit to reinvest in her business. She wants to have a successful restaurant.

This Esperanza associate began working with this group because she was interested in investing in her business, and she needed capital to improve her inventory. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, an area where the economy is dominated by agriculture.

loans.use: to buy chicken, potatoes, cooking oil, and other items.

loans.name: Resty

texts.en:
Resty is married and has three children who all go to school. She has a restaurant and has been in this business for five years. She has applied for a loan of 300,000 UGX from MCDT-SACCO to buy beef, rice, and bunches of green bananas. She sells on retail and works at the market six days a week. Her major business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. 

She aspires to own a fully stocked restaurant, buy a plot of land, and build a house. Resty resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy beef, rice, and bunches of green bananas.

loans.name: Domingas

texts.en: Domingas is applying for a loan of $600 to improve her business. She is married and has two children. She is running a business in front of her house selling palm wine. She started her business a year ago with her own working capital. Domingas lives in a town near the main road, so many people come to buy and she is selling every day. Domingas is making a good income from selling palm wine and she wants to buy more stock with this loan.

loans.use: To buy palm wine to sell.

loans.name: Ramon Aristides

texts.es:
Ramón vive en la ciudad de Ica, trabaja como vendedor en una pequeña tiene da ropa con lo cual tiene ingresos para poder salir adelante cada día, el cree que le va bien en su trabajo porque es muy carismático con los clientes y sobre todo tiene muchas ganas de mejorar.

Ramón gracias a los prestamistas kiva podrá comprar materiales para poder realizar mejoras en su vivienda y de esta manera poder mejorar su calidad de vida y seguir luchando para poder hacer realidad su gran sueño:” Tener un negocio propio”.
texts.en:
Ramón lives in the city of Ica. He works as a salesman in a small clothing store, where he earns an income to be able to get ahead each day. He thinks that he is doing well in his work because he is very charismatic with the customers and above all because he has a great desire to improve.

Thanks to the Kiva lenders, Ramón will be able to buy materials to do improvements on his home. In this way he will be able to improve his quality of life and keep striving to make his great dream a reality: ”To have his own business.”

loans.use: to buy construction materials

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
As the married mother of three children, Joyce works hard to support her family.

She has a rice retail business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a grocery store. Joyce is borrowing 50,000 PHP through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) in order to purchase more stocks of rice to offer for resale.

Joyce has been sustaining her business activities through her past 23 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of rice to offer for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a refrigerator.

loans.name: Kasi Mpya 2 Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth, who is in her late 30s, is married and has two children who are in school. Since 1999, Elizabeth has been engaged in various small businesses. One of her businesses is selling fruits and vegetables, which includes mangoes, bananas, oranges, pawpaws, tomatoes, and onions. Selling fresh juices is her second business, and she also sells door to door fabrics and cosmetics. Elizabeth works with one assistant, and she starts working from 5:00am to 10:00pm per work day.  She is able to earn a good monthly profit. 

This is her 6th loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania, which she will use to buy stock for all of her businesses. She used her previous loans, all of which has paid back in full, to increase her fruit and vegetable stock.  She also started both her fabrics and cosmetics business and fresh juice business. She is doing very well with all of her activities. Elizabeth used her profit to buy a plot of land and home fridge, and she built a house for her mother in the village. She dreams of having a better life. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "Kasi Mpya 2," which has 2 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy stock for her businesses.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia requests a $600 loan to improve her business. She has a kiosk where many people come to buy every day. She will buy some additional supplies such as onion, garlic, coffee, and sugar. She has been involved in business activities since 2012. She feels very comfortable running her business because she can earn money every day.

Running a business has made Antonia independent because she can be responsible for herself and also help her family. She hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy onion, garlic, coffee, and sugar.

loans.name: Pangkung Lip-Lip Indah Group

texts.en:
To improve the quality of their livestock, the Pangkung Lip-Lip Indah continues to take loans to buy super quality piglets for fattening. The selling prices for super quality pork remains high and these pigs are easier to sell. One member could not attend the meeting because of illness and is not in the picture.
.
Ni Kadek will use the loan to buy super quality piglets for fattening. The pigs will be fattened for six months. She hopes the pigs will be healthy and achieve an ideal weight. Ni Kadek is planning to save all the profits to use for working capital. The group expects a veterinarian will control their businesses and a training session will refresh their knowledge about pig breeding.

loans.use: to buy super quality piglets

loans.name: Carmerlita

texts.en:
Carmerlita is 34 years old, married, and has five children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Carmerlita is borrowing 10,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional feeds and vitamins to sell.

Carmerlita has been raising pigs for 5 years and also earns additional income from food vending. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional feeds and vitamins to sell.

loans.name: Dúo Bellos Amaneceres Group

texts.es: Dúo Bellos Amaneceres este grupo esta formado por la señora Elsa Alicia de 39 años de edad, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa tipica desde hace varios años, ella esta solicitando su segundo credito para la compra de ropa tipica, ya que con el credito anterior ella pudo comprar un numero mayor de ropa, en esta oportunidad ella desea comprar mas ropa en diferentes estilos ya que se aserca la fecha de fin de año y es cuando sus clientes le solicitan mas variedad en ropa tipica, el sueño de ella es tener su negocio mas grande para mejorar su calidad de vida de ella y su familia.
texts.en:
Dúo Bellos Amaneceres

Elsa Alicia is a member of this group. She is 39 years old and has made a living by selling typical clothing for many years. She is asking for her second loan to buy typical clothing, as with the previous loan she was able to buy a greater amount of clothing. At this time she wants to buy more clothing in different styles, as the end of the year is approaching and that is when her customers request the greatest variety of typical clothing. Her dream is to expand her business in order to improve her quality of life and that of her family.

loans.use: to sell typical clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy construction materials.

loans.name: Leny

texts.en:
Leny works hard to support her family. Leny is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

Leny requested a 23,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional fish to sell. Leny has been in this business for 25 years now. In the future, Leny would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell.

loans.name: Auria

texts.en:
Auria is 30 years old, and she is now applying for a loan of $1,000 to improve her business. She opened her kiosk in 2000 with her own working capital of $20. She earns a good income from her business.

She will use her loan to buy stock for her store such as soft drinks (Fanta, Coca Cola, Sprite, Sagiko), beer, milk, water, noodles, fish, bread, slippers, books, and pencils. Auria is a very hard working woman, and doing business has become her regular activity for the past 13 years. She wants to increase her business and improve her living conditions in the future.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, beer, milk, water, groceries, and other items.

loans.name: 3.09.18.02Thiệu Dương Group

texts.en:
Mai is applying for a loan to purchase flowers to resell. She operates a business selling flowers.

Mai is 39-years-old and she is married with three children.  She is the leader of a three-member group, the 3.09.18.02 Thiệu Dương solidarity group.  She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, a  rural area in Thanh Hoa province, with three dependents

This is Mai's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women.  Mai has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.  The main hardship that Mai faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Mai hopes for her business to do well, for her children to find a good job, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase flowers to resell

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en: Cristina, 35 years of age, is married to a driver and blessed with three children. She has managed a direct selling business, in which she has been selling personal use products for almost 10 years. In this business, she's earning a net income amounting PHP 1,500 weekly. Her profits are usually spent on their daily expenditures. Due to a lack of capital to use in her business, she would like a loan of PHP 28,000 to purchase shoes and clothes to sell. She's hoping that her business will continue to improve and earn more profits.

loans.use: To purchase shoes and clothes to sell.

loans.name: Renato

texts.en:
Renato is a 44-year-old man from the town of Corella, Bohol. He is married with three young children. He runs a sari-sari (variety) store. He sells various items like noodles, biscuits, sugar, coffee, detergents and toiletries. His business started quite a few years ago. He is asking for a loan to buy additional stocks like soap, canned goods, beverages, noodles and sodas to maintain the inventory of his store.

In the future, Renato hopes to expand his sari-sari store business and increase its profitability for his children’s education.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks like soap, canned goods, beverages, noodles and sodas

loans.name: Delfina
